https://prez.dev/description.@value: The types of physical samples that are used to undertake quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) checks at all stages of the sampling, preparation and analytical processes, and/or to retain representative material for future reference. Note that QA and QC are often used collectively as a single term, but are in fact distinct procedures: QA 'refers to defect prevention', i.e. ‘the protocols and procedures that ensure that sampling and assaying is completed to the required quality’, whereas QC 'refers to defect detection', i.e. ‘the use of control samples and statistical analysis to ensure that assay results are reliable’ (Graindorge, 2010, p. 112; https://www.usgs.gov/data-management/manage-quality). This vocabulary thus also encapsulates terminology covering sample representability.

A reference material submitted by the laboratory customer in a form that is indistinguishable from their samples of unknown compositions, so that the analyst is unaware that it is a reference material and thus allowing the customer to independently assess the accuracy of the analytical results.

A reference material analysed by the laboratory, along with samples of unknown compositions, to allow the laboratory to calibrate their analytical equipment or software. Calibration reference materials can also be used to monitor the accuracy of results and to allow calibration, normalisation and/or correction of unknown results within individual and across multiple analytical sessions. Calibration reference materials should be verified by an official source.

A certified reference material (CRM) is a sample material that has been prepared, typically in commercial volumes, and characterised by analysis across multiple laboratories (sometimes called 'round-robin certification'). The values for CRMs are generally well-known published figures. Elements and isotope ratios that have been characterised in this process are attributed with a certified value and uncertainty, specific to a certain analytical technique. CRMs are used to monitor accuracy and bias at the project laboratory relative to the certified values. They are also used to monitor drift over time within an individual laboratory and to identify significant failures in QC at the analytical batch level caused by abrupt changes in concentration related to re-calibration of instruments or procedural changes at the laboratory. CRMs can also be used to verify new or improved analytical techniques.
Reference material analysed by the laboratory, along with samples of unknown compositions, to allow the laboratory and/or their customers to assess the accuracy of the analytical results.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A reference material is a well-characterised sample used to monitor accuracy and bias of (analytical) measurements at the project laboratory relative to their documented values (see also certified reference materials). These samples may range from International Standards and Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) to locally prepared standard samples for use as project reference standards.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Compiled by the Geological Survey of Western Australia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A reference material is a well-characterised sample used to monitor accuracy and bias of (analytical) measurements at the project laboratory relative to their documented values (see also certified reference materials). These samples may range from International Standards and Certified Reference Materials (CRMs) to locally prepared standard samples for use as project reference standards.
